clinical_study.brief_title: A Mobile Phone Game to Prevent HIV Among Young Africans
clinical_study.official_title: A Mobile Phone Game to Prevent HIV Among Young Africans

brief_summary.textblock: This project will test the feasibility of an electronic game to prevent HIV among African preadolescents, delivered via inexpensive Android smart phones. In order to collect feasibility data for a future randomized controlled trial, this study involves the pilot-testing of the intervention with a sample of young people in Nyanza region, Kenya, where 11.4% of young women ages 15-24 are HIV-infected. This feasibility study will be carried out with the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI).

detailed_description.textblock:
This project will test the feasibility of an electronic game for preadolescents, delivered via inexpensive Android smart phones. The game is informed by socio-behavioral and pedagogical theories, evidence-based practice, and formative research on youth sexual culture in sub-Saharan Africa. It is designed to: educate young players, ages 11-14, about sexual health and HIV/AIDS; build risk-reduction skills and related self-efficacy for prevention of HIV, sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and unintended pregnancy; challenge harmful gender norms and HIV stigma; and foster dialogue with parents and caregivers.
The proposed feasibility test will be conducted in Western Kenya. Sixty preadolescents will be enrolled in the trial, 30 in the study arm and 30 in the control arm. In addition, 30 parents (one for each preadolescent in the study arm) will be enrolled to provide feedback on their experience of the study via focus group discussions. The Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) has established community advisory boards (CABs) in Kisumu, which will be available to the proposed study.
Data collection will take place at KEMRI offices, health clinics, or in the meeting room of a local community-based organization (CBO). In addition, data on game-play will be automatically collected on mobile phones given to preadolescent study participants.

primary_outcome.description: The number of participants expressing interest in participation.
The number of days needed to recruit at least 60 participants.
The number of participants who consent to participation, and cannot be be reached prior to completing all study visits.
The number of participants who complete all study visits after providing consent.
The number of phones that are not lost during the intervention.
Game acceptability will be assessed by the post-intervention survey. Questions include attitudes towards the game, phone, and content of individual modules.
Game acceptability will be assessed by focus group discussions. Semi-structured data will be collected and analyzed for major themes.
Personal safety associated with being in possession of the phone will be assessed by the post-intervention survey.
Personal safety associated with being in possession of the phone will be assessed by focus group discussions. Semi-structured data will be collected and analyzed for major themes.
The total amount of time in hours participants spend in active game play.

secondary_outcome.description: Knowledge measures will be assessed via True/False survey questions, and will address puberty, HIV, STIs, pregnancy, condoms, and alcohol & drugs.
Knowledge measures will be assessed via Yes/No survey questions, and will address perceived procedural knowledge to use condoms.

Self-efficacy will be assessed via a 3-point Likert scale, and will address self-efficacy to seek advice about puberty, sex, relationships; to communicate about protected sex; to reject peer, partner and adult pressure to engage in risk behaviors
Perceived risk will be assessed via a 3-point Likert scale, and will address perceived risk of encountering risk situations and of contracting HIV.
Perceived severity will be assessed via a 5-point Likert scale, and will address perceived severity of becoming pregnant or causing a pregnancy.

Behavioral intention will be assessed via mixed methods including Yes/No questions, a 3-point Likert scale, and a multiple-answer list. The measure will address intention to seek advice; to engage in risk situations; to delay first sex; to delay next sex (for those who have had sex); to use a condom at first sex; to use a condom at next sex (for those who have had sex).
Future orientation will be assessed via a multiple-choice question or a 3-point Likert, will address expected educational attainment and perceived locus of control.
Perceived social norms will be assessed via a 3-point Likert and will address early sex, consent, girls' education, gender-based violence, condom use, and HIV stigma.

arm_group.description: Participants randomized to this arm will be invited to play the Tumaini game.
Participants randomized to this arm will receive no intervention beyond the current standard of care for sexual education.

intervention.description: Tumaini is a scenario-based role-playing game application, optimized for use on low-cost Android smartphones. Participants will be invited to play the game for at least ten hours over a period of three weeks. The game is designed to: educate players about sexual health and HIV/AIDS; build risk-reduction skills and related self-efficacy for prevention of HIV/STIs and unintended pregnancy; challenge HIV stigma and harmful gender norms; and promote parent-child dialogue.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria
Preadolescents:
- Aged 11-14 at time of recruitment
- Resident in Nyanza region, Kenya
- Having basic literacy in English
- Only one child per family
Parents:
- Parent/primary caregiver of child aged 11-14 at time of recruitment
- Resident in Nyanza region, Kenya
Exclusion criteria
Preadolescents:
- Aged <11 or >14 at time of recruitment
- Not resident in Nyanza region, Kenya
- Without basic literacy in English
- Sibling to a child already enrolled in the study
- Participant in formative research to inform the study
Parents:
- Not parent/primary caregiver of child aged 11-14 at time of recruitment
- Not resident in Nyanza region, Kenya
- Participant in formative research to inform the study
